identificationModule.briefTitle: Operant Conditioning of the Soleus Stretch Reflex in Adults With Cerebral Palsy
identificationModule.officialTitle: Operant Conditioning of the Soleus Stretch Reflex in Adults With Cerebral Palsy

descriptionModule.briefSummary: 12 adults with spastic CP will complete 6 baseline sessions and 24 down conditioning sessions held 3 times/week. All clinical and physiological assessments collected at baseline will be reassessed after study completion, and follow ups after 2 weeks, 1 month and 3 months. The soleus H reflex (electric analogue of the stretch reflex) will be elicited in all sessions. In each session, participants will complete 20 baseline trials and 225 down conditioning trials to decrease the magnitude of the H-Reflex.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: Individuals with CP face significant challenges due to spasticity that causes activity and participation restrictions with increase in secondary conditions. This is caused by injury to the upper motor neurons causing disruption to the neural circuitry responsible for maintaining motor tone. A novel intervention, OC of the H reflex has shown promising effects to reduce spasticity and improve motor function in people with stroke and spinal cord. Its many known benefits include easy administration, non-invasive technique, no side effects, and long-term retention. In the study, the investigators will attempt to decrease the increased muscle tone of individuals with CP. If successful, it will not only provide evidence for future clinical application but also broaden the scope for alternate or supplementary non-invasive treatment approaches to decrease spasticity.

designInfo.interventionModelDescription: Each participant will serve as their own control.

armGroups.label: Spinal reflex conditioning
armGroups.description:
The OC intervention includes 6 baseline sessions and 24 conditioning/ no conditioning sessions held 3 times/week.

To elicit an H-reflex, participants will be asked to stand in a comfortable position. Small pulses of energy will be applied to a nerve in the leg called the tibial nerve. We will record when the participant maintains leg muscle activity. During the intervention, participants will be trained to decrease their reflex in their calf.

interventions.name: Spinal reflex conditioning
interventions.description: Each participant will serve as their own control. The intervention is 30 sessions. The first 6 sessions are baseline measures of reflexes. The remaining sessions will engage participants in learning how to decrease their reflex activity in their calf muscle on the more-affected leg. Each intervention visit will involve 20 trials in which participants do not get visual feedback about their performance, then 225 trials with visual feedback.

primaryOutcomes.description: Size of h-reflex as measured by EMG
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Within one week before first intervention session to within one week after the end of intervention

primaryOutcomes.description: Measure of feasibility of protocol, whether or not people can attend all sessions
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At the end of the intervention, we will count the number of sessions each participant completed

secondaryOutcomes.measure: 10 meter walk test
secondaryOutcomes.description: Measure of how long it takes the participant to walk 10 meters
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Within one week before the first intervention session to within one week after the end of intervention

secondaryOutcomes.measure: 6 minute walk test
secondaryOutcomes.description: Measure the distance a participant can walk in 6 min
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Within one week before the first intervention session to within one week after the end of intervention

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Fugl-Meyer
secondaryOutcomes.description: Standardized test of motor skill, range of motion, and spasticity
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Within one week before the first intervention session to within one week after the end of intervention

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Modified Ashworth Scale
secondaryOutcomes.description: Measure of muscle spasticity in leg muscles
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Within one week before the first intervention session to within one week after the end of intervention

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Range of motion
secondaryOutcomes.description: Measure of flexibility of leg joints
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Within one week before the first intervention session to within one week after the end of intervention

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Fatigue Severity Scale
secondaryOutcomes.description: A survey of fatigue symptoms
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Within one week before the first intervention session to within one week after the end of intervention

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Berg Balance Scale

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Timed up and Go
secondaryOutcomes.description: Measure of how quickly a participant can stand from a chair, walk, return to chair, and sit

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Sit to Stand Test
secondaryOutcomes.description: Time it takes for a participant can stand up five times in a row

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in size of motor evoked potential in the brain
secondaryOutcomes.description: Using single pulse transcranial magnetic stimulation, we will measure the amount of energy required to evoke a leg muscle movement from a stimulus delivered to the head
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Within one week before the first intervention session to within one week after the end of intervention

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Manual Ability Classification System
secondaryOutcomes.description: A categorical measure of how well a participant can move their hands
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Within one week before the first intervention session to within one week after the end of intervention

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Jebsen-Taylor Test of Hand Function
secondaryOutcomes.description: A timed test that measures how quickly the participant can move checkers, cans, and small objects
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Within one week before the first intervention session to within one week after the end of intervention

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

1. Age 18 and above
2. Diagnosis of spastic Cerebral Palsy
3. Gross Motor Function Classification System level I-III
4. Stable medical background
5. Current medication will remain unchanged for 3 months
6. Provides informed consent
7. can walk at least 10 meters with or without assistive device
8. meets minimum study procedure requirements (elicitation of H-reflex).

Exclusion Criteria:

1. Pregnancy
2. uncontrolled diabetes
3. weak dorsiflexion
4. History of cardiac conditions
5. cognitive deficits that interfere with study procedure and steps for completion
6. Botox within 2 months of the study
7. H/O ankle surgeries in affected leg (Dorsal root rhizotomy etc.)
8. regular use of electrical stimulation to lower extremity muscles
9. Cochlear or metal implantations on body
10. No history of seizure after age 2 years
11. Current use of antiseizure medicines
12. Any metal or magnetic components in the head (surgical clips, metal work etc.)
13. Implanted device or cardiac pacemakers (applicable for DS8R too)
14. Skin disorders
15. Damaged skin (wounds, broken skin, or recent scar tissue)
16. Allergy to latex (tape)

references.citation: Thompson AK, Chen XY, Wolpaw JR. Soleus H-reflex operant conditioning changes the H-reflex recruitment curve. Muscle Nerve. 2013 Apr;47(4):539-44. doi: 10.1002/mus.23620. Epub 2012 Dec 21.

Mrachacz-Kersting N, Kersting UG, de Brito Silva P, Makihara Y, Arendt-Nielsen L, Sinkjaer T, Thompson AK. Acquisition of a simple motor skill: task-dependent adaptation and long-term changes in the human soleus stretch reflex. J Neurophysiol. 2019 Jul 1;122(1):435-446. doi: 10.1152/jn.00211.2019. Epub 2019 Jun 5.

ipdSharingStatementModule.description: We will email deidentified datasets to other researchers upon request. When we publish our results, we will mention in the paper(s) that the dataset is fully available via email.
ipdSharingStatementModule.timeFrame: Data will be available as soon as the findings are published, and will be available indefinitely.
ipdSharingStatementModule.accessCriteria: We will provide data to researchers who have experience with operant conditioning data analyses.
